To find the lengths of other mastes by numbers.
Let the bredth: (ga, or ea) be
taken in tenths of a foote & then
ab=52427, ac=1296
& so for any others.
Invented this: Feb: 28th 1607/1608.
& gave it to E. Marlow
for Mr Baker the shipwrite.

This way therefore the calculation may
be also made.

I am of opinion that depth is to be
regarded with the bredth for the length of
the mastes: for put the case I have the
mast length for 20 foot broad & 10 foote
deep, which is 60 foot as in the table.

And then I keeping the bredth
wold have my ship of [???]
lesser depth as 7 foot; the maste is
also to be shorter. & then consider whether
whether the shortening of ac the latus rectum in proportion to the depth
will bring forthe the length of the second maste or not.

The length of the ship in this reckoning I thinkw also to be like
regarded because, when the mast is fitted for bredth &
depth, it cannot be amisse for the longest dimension.
Therefore I make the rule thus:

[Note:
The problem of finding a circle touching two given points and a given line is here called the 'Problema naupegicum', though is not clear from these pages exactly how this problem is relevant to ship-building. Harriot notes that he has met the problem elsewhere, in the pages of Pappus, Book 7, where it is attributed to Apollonius. It seems that at this time Harriot was not yet as familiar with the work of Apollonius as he later became. For much more work on this and related problems, see his notes on Viète's Apollonius Gallus (1600).
Observe that where Harriot moves into formal mathematics he also begins to write in Latin.
]

div.head: Problema Naupegicum

p.s:
Hinc problema unum Appoloniacum solvitur,

ex. lib. Appol.

[tr: This problem is an Apollonian one, solved, of which mention is made in Pappus, Book 7, on the Book of Apollonius, page 159.
]

cæteri casus

[tr: Other cases, possible and impossible, are easily understood, see the other page. ]
[Note: The other sheet referred to here is the reverse of this one, Add MS 6788, f. 8v, which lists some possible and impossible cases. ]

bi et ie datis, be nota erit.
[...]
Igitur hs est media proportionalis inter bs et es, et nota
centrum A erit in concursum perpendicularium hA et fA.
Dabuntur etiam ch et hd. vel il et le. il=le. quia Ale rectus.
In triangulo etb dantur duo latera et angulus teb; ergo omnia latera
et Ah semidiameter peripheriæ circumscribentis dabuntur in numeris
canonis per doctrinam triangulorum, et etiam in partibus bc primo datis.
[tr: If bi and ie are given, be will be known.
[...]
Therefore hs is the mean proportional between bs and es, and the known centre A will be at the metting point of the perpendicular hA and fA.
Also ch and hd are given, or il and le; and il=le because Ale is a right angle.
In the triangle etb there are given two lines and the angle teb; therefore all the sides and Ah, the semidiameter of the circumscribed circumference are given in tabulated numbers by the doctrine of triangles, and also in terms of bc, given at the beginning. ]

Et sine doctrina triangulorum in hinc modum quæsita inveninuntur:
[tr: And without the doctrine of traingles, what is sought may be found by this method: ]

Facillima
operatio notatur
notatur *
[tr: Most easily the working may be denoted as at * ]

Sit recta linea inter duo puncta data:
[tr: Let the straight line be between the two given points: ]
Mr. Fr: Godolphin

div.head:
Problema Appolonicum aliud. vide Pappum. lib. 7. pag. 159.
[tr: Another problem of Apollonius, see Pappus, Book 7, page 159. ]

p.s:
Datis duobus punctis intra peripheriam circuli: per illa puncta
et terminos Diametri circuli dati, peripheriam circuli ducere.
[tr: Given two points inside the circumference of a circle, through those points and the ends of the diameter of the given circle, draw the circumference of a circle. ]

Data.
a. b. puncta.
[tr: Given, the points a, b. ]

Ex ista constructione
cæteri casus facile
intelligantur.
[tr: From this construction, other cases are easily understood. ]

Usus in planisphæ-
rio ptolomaico.
[tr: Used in the planisphere of Ptolemy. ]

Sit iam factum. Et peripheria circuli transiens per data puncta sit abch
cuius centrum g. Et cfe diameter circuli dati. a punctis a et b datis ducuntur
per centrum f, lineæ afh et bfm. Rectangulum ex cf et fe; hoc est quadratum
ex fe, æquantur rectangulo ex af et fh; vel bf et fm. Ergo fe est media
proportionalis inter af et fh.
[tr: Suppose it already done. And let the circumference of the circle passing through the given points be abch, whose centre is g. And cfe is the diameter of the given circle. From the given points a et b there are drawn through the centre f, the lines afh and bfm. The product of cf and fe, that is, the square of fe, is equal to the product of af and fh, or of bf and fm. Therefore fe is the mean proportional between af and fh. ]

Problema igitur perficitur ad hunc modum. A punctis datis a et b ducantur rectæ
ad centrum f. af et bf. ad af et a puncto f, sit fd perpendicularis, ut
ducatur recta ad. et a puncto d erigatur perpendicularis do. producatur
af et concurret cum do in puncto h. a medio ah fit perpendicularis ig
et a mdeio ab sit perpendicularsi kr. secabit iq in puncto g. quod est centrum
peripheriæ quæsitæ. demonstratio manifesta ex propertate superius allata. &c.
[tr: The problem is therefore brought about in this way. From the given points a et b there are drawn the lines af and bf to the centre f. Let fd be perpendicular to af at the point f, so that there is drawn the line ad. And form the point d there is erected the perpendicular do. The line af is extended and meets do in the point h. From the middle of ah there is constructed the perpendicular ig, and from the middle of ab the perpendicular kr will cut iq in the point g, which is the centre of the sought circumference. The demonstration is clear from the property reported above. etc. ]

Si dentur ab, af, bf, et ce in numeris; Dabuntur etiam in iisdem ig et kg
nam angulus bah cogitus est ex data triangulo abf. Dantur ab et ah. notum igitur
bh. et diameter circumscribentis peripheriæ per doctrinam triangulorum. &c.
[tr: If there are given ab, af, bf, and ce in numbers, there will be given also in the same way ig and kg, for the angle bah is known from the given triangle abf. The lines ab and ah are given, therefore bh is known, and the diameter of the circumference of the circumscribing circle from the doctrine of triangles. etc. ]

[Note:
This folio provides a canon, or rule, for finding the square root of a quantity d+f.
Using the fundamental property established in the first line, the first term in the canon can be rewritten as the square root of
bb+cc2+(bb+cc)24+4bc4
=bb.
Similarly, the second term yields cc. Thus the sum of the square roots yields b+c, as required.
A numerical example is worked at the bottom of the page.
]

div.head: Of ropes

p.s: 11. Catharpins. to keepe the shroudes tought.

[Diagram]
shroudes
dedmaneye

12. collars of the stayes are short ropes coming about the
mastes (or timber) bothe endes being spliced & brought
about a dedmaneye, & the lower ende of the stay hath
a ded deadmaneye also, thourough which eyes are is reeved
a rope to & fro to fasten make the stay & coller
tought together & this rope is called a lanier.
And the ends of the shroudes are dedmen eyes, & in the
chaynes are other ded men eyes; & those dedmen eyes
are coupled with lannieres.

13. Standing takles are within the shroudes, having having
only a pendent with a long blocke of two shiners one above
an other, the end of the pendent is fast under the top. then there
is a blocke of two shiners (parallel) with a hooke below hitching
into a ring on the chaynewale, unto this blocke is fast a rope
which is reeved thourough a shiner of the lower blocke & so up agayne & downe
to be set taught to stay the mastes till the shrouds be set
& stand stil after to strengthen the shroudes.

Gunners takles, have hookes & blockes; & are to be removed
& taken away at pleasure. & serve to bouse these peeces
in & out; & to remove them from place to place.
to bouse. i. hale
[???] bouse here

div.head: Of ropes

p.s:
6.) The sprit sayle hath clew lines like the topsayles
but no bowlinges. & sheates but no tackes.
hath also liftes as the other yardes.

He hath garnets, one cometh from the middlest of the
the arme, to a blocke towards the top of the boltsprit
and so cometh downe by the boltsprit to the beake hed to
be haled. His office to ease the lift & to help the sayle
vere by a wind. So the other.

The misons have but one lift which cometh from the top of
the small end above, of the yard, & is reeved thourough a
pully at the top of the mast & so cometh downe.
hathe hath one sheat, fast, at at the right angle, & cometh to a blocke in
a bumkin without the ship asterne & so cometh in to be haled
or thourough a blocke made fast aloft in the midst in
aftermost part of the ship aloft & from there a little
forward to be haled.
His tacke is fast at the sharpe tayle (sharp angle aslo)
& his other end is rope to be brought over to the
wether side & there to be belayed to a kebble.

The bowlinges are two ropes fast
to the lower end of the yard (with a
button of wood & an eye) and from there
are reeved in two pullyes made
fast to the aftermost mayne shroude
one on the one side & and the other on the
other. the bowlinge is to be halyed
when they will go set their mizon to
go by a wind.
When the sayle is furled, & the yard up, they
being both hauled & belayed do steddy the yard in the
middest of the ship.

[Diagram] mison sayle
sheat

div.head: Of ropes

p.s:
10. Bowlinges (bowlines)
Of the mayne bowling, half a blocke or pully fitted fast about a one end
is spliced fast about a pully having a shiner, & thourough that
shiner passes a short rope having two deadmeneyes spliced
at the two endes thereof, thourough whihch eyes come other
small ropes making crow feet are spliced into the side
bolt rope of the mayne sayle; this parte from the pully is called
the bowling bridles; the other end of the bowling is reeved
thourough a block made fast with a strap nere towards
the foremaste on the top of the forecastle in the middest (of
bredth) & from thence comes aft towards the mayne
maste there to be haled. & is belayed about kebble or some
bitte. And thourough a shiner of the same blocke on
the fore castle passes the bowling up the other side.
And his use is when they go by a wind (the tackes
being abord) & sheates haled aft) then to be haled tought
& belayde; that the wether leech (side) be kept tought
& and not to lift or shake in the wind.

In like manner the fore bowlinge come thourough a blocke
with a double shiner made fast about the middest of
the bolt sprit & so comes thourough a blocke fast at the
lower parte of the boltsprit (above the head beke) one
one side (for on the other is an other) & so cometh into the
the forecastle or up alofte there to be haled & belayed.

The two top sayle bowlings are reeved thourough two blockes sezed
to the topmast stay & the & the mayne topsayle boweling once
reeved agayne thourough two blockes fast about the rayles of the after
part of the forecastle & so into the ship to be haled.
but the foretopsayle bowlings are agayne thourough
two pullyes fast towards the top of teh boltsprit (& so to
the top fo foretop then to be haled) or are reeved agayne
agayne in two pullys at the lower part of the boltsprit
& thence to the forecastle to be haled.

div.head: Of ropes

p.s:
The foresayle hath sheates and tackes made fast to teh clewes
in like manner as the mayne sayle.
One end of the sheat is fastened at the middest of the maste or nere on
the out side, & so reeved thourough the block with a strap at the clew
& reeved thourough a pully shiner in the ships side nere the mayne
maste & there is to be haled & belayed about a kebble nere hand.

The foretackes goe thourough two holes in a cleate (a peece of wood nayled
to the bomkin (like a peece of a maste under the beake head fastened [???] in
bord) the small endes passing thourough are brought up on the contrary
side of the fore maste throug orover the forecastle & there to be haled
to bring the tacke abord; where is the clew to the bomkin or as nere as it can.

7. the Clew garnet of the maynesayle one end is fastened at the clew & the
other reeved thourough a blocke fastened under the mayne yard
towarde the maste on the same side or arme & so cometh downe to be
haled to bring the clewes to the yard when the sayle is striken downe
& then they use to furle up the sayle & ty it up with gaskets
(yarn platted with nooses at the greater end) fastened with a rope yarn
to a grummet (a nayle with a ring) driven into the yard & coming about
the sayle they make it fast in a other grummet. They are many of them
alongst the yard, but the middle two (or 4) being greater &
longer than the rest are called breech gaskets; & when the
sayle is to be let fall they order as many as they can & then cut
the rope yarnes of the breech gaskets last of all & both together.

8. The Martenet line, one end is fastened under the top & reeved thourough
thourough a double pully with 3 shiners (2 one way & one another) that is
thourough the single shiner & so comes backe to a pully under the top & so
goes downe by the foremost shorude there to be haled; thourough the double
shiners of the pully come one on one side & the other on
the other of the yard; at whose endes are dead men eyes. And thourough
the holes of the dead men eyes are peeces of small line bothe endes of
which line are spliced fast into the bolterope on the side & make
crow feet. The us by is by haling the martenet line to bring
the sayle close to the yard at the yardarmes end & forwards
In like sort also are the martenets of the foresayle.

The luffe hooke, is a rope with a hooke having an eye or
hole, thorugh which a rope is reeved & spliced; whose use
put the hooke into the earing of the clew of the sayle
if only the bonnet be on; or bonnet if drabble be on & the
other end goeth thourough a hole in the ships side & there is haled
in tought & belayed to helpe the tacke for feare of breaking.
the mayne & foresayle only have this luffe hooke.

[Diagram]
a dead man eye
a luffe hooke

div.head:
Of ropes.
for sayles.

p.s:
4. Sheates; which are fatened to the clewes (lower corners
like nooses or eares alofte)
of the mayne topsayle sheat, one end is fast to the clew
of the top sayle & is reeved thourough a blocke made fast
to the end of the mayne yard arme, & thourough an other
blocke fast on the same yard arme nere the maste &
so cometh down to a shener in a poste upon the deck nere
the maste. & serveth to hale out the clewes to the end
of the mayne yard arme.

5. The clew line. is a rope fast to the same clew (or corner)
& is reeved thourough a block fast to the top sayle yard
nere the midest of the yard arme on the same side, & so
cometh downe thourough a hole in the mayne top to a hole
& thourough a peece of wood bond fast to the one of the mayne
shroudes on the same side; & there to be haled & fastened
in taking in the sayle.

His office is to hale downe the top sayle (halyendes
being let go.) & to hale up the clewes to the top sayle
yard arme, the top sayle sheates being let go in taking it in.
in like manner the foretopsayle.

To the clew of the maynesayle is fastened a blocke with a strap
and a button at the end by putting the button thourough and a noose,
then one end of the main sheat is fast to a ring bolt
on the out side of the ship in the after part about the galley
& is reeved thourough the sayd block with a strap, & so cometh
reeved agayne thourough the mayne sheat block fastened
to the ship side with a strap in a ring bolt. & so cometh into the
ship to be halyd. & is to be belayed about a kebble; which is
a peece of wood fast to the ship side.
his office is to hale aft the clew of the sayle.

6. The mayne tacke, is fashioned taperwise bigger at one end then the other
at the great end is a knot like a button which is thrust thourough the nooose
of the clew, the noose of the strap of the sayd blocke being first put out or
e contra, so it is then fastened to the clew of the mayne sayle
& the samller end cometh into a hole thourough the ship side
out the luffe which is nere the forecastle at the bow agaynst the pitch of
the sterne, & is haled within bord thourough that hole, & belayed about
some kebble at the ships sides or at the upper bitte. his office is to hale forward
the rayle untill it come abord the close aboard the ship side.

div.head: Of ropes

p.s:
3. Slinges. a rope for the mayne yard & fore yarde used sometimes when the
yard is up to faten it or hang it in. least the [???] breake
or be shot asunder.

4. brases. for all the yardes. except mizon yarders. fastened at the endes of the yardes
& running thourough pullyes to turne about the yardes.

5. liftes. for all the yardes. fastened at the endes of the yardes
& coming thourough pullyes alofte; to lift the endes of the yardes
up: not the yardes them selves.

6. In great ships only. The gere. to ease the tyes in hoysing
& when it is up aloft also. for mayne and foreyarde only.

7. puddinges. short peeces of ropes nayled about the yardes
about a foot or 112 asonder to keep the Raubins
(of the sayles) from slipping or sliding.

b. the brases have a pendent part fastened at
the endes of the yardes with a block (as the tackles)
& a running part. one end fast; & the other end
to hale by. it reeved thourough the block of the
pendent.

a rope is unreeved when he is out of the
pully. reve the rope. i. put him inot his pully.

div.head: ropes for sayles

p.s:
1. bolt rope, that goeth round about the sayle into which the
rayle is sowed; the uppermost is called the head rope
(side rope, foot rope) leech line (side line) there use.

2. (Cringles I thnke) that go round about the aylet holes like a
lace to strengthen them.

3. Raubins, made fast in the aylet holes alofte & go round about
the yardes & tyed; betwen the puddinges which keep them from
sliding or slipping.

The earinges. which are nooses at the corners of the sayle
are fastened to the endes of the yard armes with such rope
many times thourough.

backe stayes of the foretopmast, from the top thereof to the aftermost parte of
the forecastle 2 or 3.

The mastes themselves have no back stayes; but there shroudes that
come from the crosse trees under the tops to there chayne wales.
made faste there with lanniers (ropes going thourough dead men eyes to hale
them tought) the peeces of wood with a ring of [???] & holes in them made
fast to chaynes under the cheyne wales are the dead men eyes.
In like manner are the other mastes.
But the top mast shroudes come to the brim of the top & are fastened with
lanniers thourough dead men eyes like the other.

All the top mastes have a forestay & backe stayes. backstayes are standing
backestaye & backestaye; two standing backestayes on either side
one belongs to one top mast made to the out side of the ship; & the other within
being also two.

div.head: yardes

p.s: 1. haliers, to hoyse them up with all, going thourough thourough the ra head and teh Knight.

2. tyes, fatened to the yardes coming thourough the houndes
which are holes thourough the cheekes (at the head of
the mastes) bearing up the crosse tree, having being
put thourough the vam head.

The Mayne Knight is a peece of timber fast upon the slope
or second deck bolted fast to some beame. Having
shiners in it (wheles of pullyes) so that the mayne haliers
go thourgh the upper decks.

The fore Knight such an other thourough which the fore haliers come but fastened to the a
beame about the afterward part of the forecastle also upon the
slope or lower deck.

div.head: Ropes.

p.s:
One end of the Cable is to be brought ont at the Hawse
and bent (mad fast) to the rynge of the Anchore, then
the other end must be brought to the Bytte (two upright
postes with a crosse peece of tymber bolted fast to beames alowe)
and ther be belayde.

then ther is a Bwye with a bwye rope, which rope is mad fast
to the corsse of the Anchore, by which the anchore is to be wayd which
a boat as occasion serveth.

in letting fale the Anchore which hangeth in a stopper (as they
cale it) a cock bylle ready to let fale, that when the master caleth
they cast of the stoper) lett fale: then when ther are many hands
readye to over sette the fakes of the cable and followe it for feare
of kinks, and one standeth by the stopper that when they crye
stope he presently clapes the stopper about the cable and vers
agayne as he is bydd the master as the shype cranes untyle
shee be brought upe to a Bytter.

The stopper is a strong rope about a fathome longe one end
wherof is fast to the shypps syde (afore by the mange neer the
Hawse.) at some rynge boult) or havinge a knott at one end is
thrust thorowhe a hole in some stronge peece of tymber standinge
conveniently neere the foresayd place, the other end is loose to be
suddenly brought about the cable two or .3. tyms to stoppe it.
And in wayinge they cast one the stopper upon the cable, and then
cat it off at the Bytte & brynge the end to the capsten [???].

When the Anchor is upe to the Hawser thyey have a great yron hooke
to which a rope is fast which is caled a fyshhooke, they lett it downe and
heech it about one of the flowkes of the Anchore, & bringe the Rope
out to the end of a great peece of tymber thrust out over the syde
(which they cale a Davitt) & then cry hale fish &c.

Ther is one either syde the shyppbefore a peece of tymber fast to
the shype syde standinge out with a shyner at the ende, caled the catte
throwe which shyner they reeve a rope caled the catt rope one ende
wher of they fasten to the rynge of teh Anchore & hange this rope
putinge out the cable at the hawse they bringe it upe, & then with
takels they bringe the Anchor to the Bowe agayne. hale out &c.

the greatest Anchor they cale the shoote Anchor the other Bowers
ther is a smale Anchor with a longe cabled hawser which is caled
a kedginge Anchor to warpe upon when occasion serveth.

they lay out thsi smale Anchor with ther boat & bringinge the end
aborde they heave the shipe to it & then lett drope another smale
anchor under foote, & then lay out the kedginge anchor againe which
they cale warpinge &c.

this is used to gett out of a harbore when the wynd which bloweth
would serve yf you were without the harbore, but they use it not but
in fayre weather when the wynd doth not over blowe, for this
lytle anchor would not then hould the shyppe.

div.head: Notes.

p.s:
The keele in a ship (100 t) of 12 yardes deep; 10 yardes broad
The sterne post & stern are below as the keele
but a loft the stern is thicker in & out (& otherwise also)
it ends in a quadrant, & comes into the beake head as a stump.
the beake hed is 15 or 16 of the keele in length.
The timbers (of 100 t) of the midship bend, are 7 inches in & out
below & 8 inches brode, & a lofte about 3 inches every way.
The lower wales are in thicknesse 5 yardes, & about 6 in bredth, the other are lesse
the planke between is 3 inches & so down to the keele, upward they
are thinner by degrees.

Upon the keel, the floore timbers of the bendes are fastened with trennels; upon the
floore timbers the keelson runns alonge, being bolted to the keel in
divers places between the floore bendes. then on both sides
the keelson is floored with plankes.

The A ship is sayd to leake in the hoodings when the leakes at the
stern where the endes of the plankes are fastened. Mr Barker devised a
false stern joyning to the other whereupon the plankes are better
fastened. (I thinke it better to be called a sternson.)
A David.

is the timber that receveth the tops

The thicke planckes that runne fore & aft with on the inside of

sleepers, are of the nature of footewales to helpe them.

The plankes of great ships underwater in & between the two lower wales

There are two or 3 tackles of a side bolt to the mayne mast

And I think the foreyard is 34 of the mayne.

In a ship of 20f broad, the mayne mast is usually 20 yards.
In a ship of 40f (the Kings) brode, the mayne mast 32 yards.
In a ship of 16, foot broade; the mayne mast: 16 yardes and 4 foote.

The place where the maste goeth thourough the decke is
called the partners. They say: The mast is so many

Serving of ropes, is with rope yarne wound round about to save them
from fretting agaynst wood.

Whipping of ropes endes. with twyne to fasten the ende to keep him
from fazing out: i. riveling.

Kinking of a cable, or stiffe rope. a fold that happens when
the cable runneth out to fast & it doubles; for want of well
oversetting the flakes in paying out of it; & then they say
stopp stop to get out the kink.
A flake fake is one bout of the coyle of a cabble.
A coyle of ropes. they coyle with the sonne. to coyle.

A log line.

Takles. are ropes whose one end is made fast at the head of the
maste & the other end hath a great pully or blocke with a shiner in it
& that part they call a pendent. then there is a blocke fast
at the chayne wale having shiners ring in the cheyne
wale into which is put a hooke fastened to a block
with shiners (a great pully). Then there is a standing
parte of the takle which goeth thourough the blocke of the
pendent & and hath one other bl a long block with two shiners
one above an other at one end, & the other end is reeved (put)
thourough the sayd ring & there fastened about the ring to it self.
Then there is a running part one end fastened to the foresayd block
with the hooke & so rived thourough the upper shiner of the block
of the standing part & one shiner
of the blocke with the hooke & so up
& downe agayne by the second
shiner of the blocke with hooke
& then the end to be haled &
to be fastened when they have
don about all the parts &c.

div.head:
Notes taken out Captayne Edmund Marloe his booke
intituled Ars Naupegica. or the art of ship building.

p.s:
The Easterling, Dues or Fleming, build floty ships by reason those
countryes are subiect to flats & shoulds. And because they often bring
them a ground they have much flat flore to rest them on. There sides
also are upright, and are built so for burthen & small draught of water.
And they beare sayle not so much for there sides, but by reason of the
great weyght that lyeth below upon the flore, (being so broad & long).
But these for the most part are evill conditioned ships in the sea:
being subiect to rowle, tumble, & leape in a wrought sea; so that
you must allwayes keep some sayle abrode.

Contrarywise the Spaniard (not accustomed to bring his ships a ground)
but allwayes to ride aflote, and also to trimme his ships upon the
carine) buildeth sharpe deep ships, hanging of for the most part upon
the nayle. As you may se by there Carbells. And there Caractes
likewise for the most part flare much of aloft. Now these hold a
better wind & are easier in a wrought sea, and will commonly hull well,
& wether quoyle. But they draw much water & are not well to be brought
a ground without good floring for feare they fall over.

The Frenchmen are nearest to perfection in bearing style & going
well, being neat moulded ships. But they are not commmonly so great
in burthen as they loome for. They have lolng rakes & sharp forward
on; and there decks steeve much forward. Where contrarywise, the
Easterling & Dues have short upright rakes & bloof ships forwards
on. Also there decks steeve or hung afterwardes on.

But our English ships are intended to have such perfection, that
(according to the intent of the builder) they hold burden with the
Fleming; bearing with the Spaniard; going well with the French &c.

Every nation aymeth at this to have there ships go well & stear well
which proceedeth especially from the well weying of a ship fore & afte
for the Runne & Tuck.

These are the cheif propertyes of a ship in the sea. TO go well; to
stear well, & beare a good sayle. As for the Burthen that belongeth
to the owners profit, which some to much affecting hath made us to
have so many furred ships.

Some have made a ship of 19 foot brode, to be 8 foot and a 12 in houlde, where-
by to carry three tyre of Burdeux cask, which cannot welbe don
in lesse then 21 feet brode. They have been fayne afterwards (when
they see to there greef that she will beare no sail) to fur her at
least a foot on a side more; all which is lost in hold to there hindrance.

div.head: Notes.

p.s:
It is knowne by experience that a ship whose depth. 10, foote
bredth. 20
length 50 by the keele
is of burden a 100 tonne.

Mr. Baker makes this rule & findes it
little more or lesse than the truth otherwise tried:
he makes a solid nomber of 10. 20. & 50; & then
devides it by a hundred; the quotient is the tonnes of burden; (in hold as I take it)
the sayd length depth & bredth must be in feete for this rule.

ffor tonne & tonnage of the Kinges ships he multiplyes as before
but devides by 70. & the quotient is counted her tonnage.
By these rules the tonnage of shipps is measured for the King.

Tonne & tonnage is what a ship doth carry of ordinaure mastes
sayles & yardes, together with that which she carry in hold: &c.

Ths solid nomber of 10. 20. 50. is: 10,000. And so many solide feet
is that parallelepiped.
Now it semeth to me that that parallelepipied is to the bulke of the
ship as 3 to 1. or nere. for devide the nomber by 3 & then
the bulke bulke of the hsip is, 3,333. in feet. then every solide foot
holding 64 pound of water; I multiply it by 64 and it amounteth
to in pounds, 213, 312. which devided
by .2240. yieldeth 95, tonne. 20 times 112lb being
the tonne.
but by 2000, yieldeth 106. tonne. reckoning 20 times
100, only for the tonne.
And so Mr Bakers rule
happeneth to be the meane.

In deviding it by 70, the
tonnage it is 143 tonnes.
That tonne being 2,240lb
maketh the above sayd parall-
epiped to be just double to
the bulke. Therefore 5000
multiplied by 64 maketh
320,000lb & devided by
2240. yieldeth 143.

But of this matter more is to be considered
by the true solidity of the ship gotten by
geometrciall measure. &c.

The caracte taken by Sr J. Barres
length. 100. foot
breadth. 47. f
depth. 31. f
by this recconing
of 1457. tonne
but counted 1600. tonne

div.head: Of the fashion peece.

p.s:
The inner playne of the fashion peece tieth in the line ** which
is best to be made parallell, to the sterne post or if not parallell
to make an obsu obtuser angle somewhat with the sterne keele.
but in this plot inclineth somewhat the contrary way by which
this fashion peece is made. it is best that the uppermost starre
stand in an even bend (which here is the 23th) in uppermost rising
line. where Therefore in the parallell for the 23th bend
in the playne of bredth & length is to be taken the length & bredth
the narrowing & bredth a loft for the fashion peece.
to which narrowing, ee is æquall; so that ke is the bredth a lofte.
The lower starre standing in the rising line [???] is
represented by v, so that kv is æquall to ** in the plot by qs. vÏ† is æquall to
the rest of that line in the same playne to the line aG.
va is æquall to the narrowing alow taken in the parallell that passeth
by the lower starre. ab & aβ is æquall to ab & aβ of the midship
bend. here b & β are over gon of one the other (on contrary
sides) so that there is no floore.

β* & b* sheweing the soothmarkes are æquall (as in all the bends)
to those of the midship mould.
b & β being known, the centers m and μ, are knowne & all the rest
as in the 16th bend, & so the descriptions of the arkes.

Then understand the forke here described to be away (for it is to
shold not have ben don) & the [???] the mouldes cutting one an
other of geveth the the whole fashioin a little above v leaveth the rest for the fashion
peece.

div.head: The 16th bend. abaft.

p.s:
Make the line kÏ† æquall to the perpendicular in the plot from the rising
a loft to the keel upon the 16 bend. Ï†v æquall to the rising alow
Then let ke be æquall to ke in the plot. ee the narrowing aloft
then ke is the 12 bredth of this bend. kv the depth of this bend.
make va æqualal to the narrowing below of this bend in the plott
let ab & aβ be æquall to ab amp; aβ of the midship bend.
then bβ is the floore of this bend.
β* & b* shewing the sooth markes are æquall always in every bend
to those of the midship mould.
from the sooth marke to to kv is æquall tp the halfe breadth below. (found in the plott.)

Then for the centers thus: βμ, bm: oc, od: en, er: ar æquall to
the same sweepes in the midship bend. likewise, on, om: æquall th to the
on, om in the sayd midship bend.
So that hereby mechanically are described the arkes ed, dc, cb; & there
correspondents.

Then at Ï†, downwards is to be allowed 2 inches in small shippes (of 100t)
& 3 ynches (of 800t)
for dead rising for the timber hole; where the timber must be so broad as the keel
& this is to be allowed in the midship bend and all the rest
then from the upper edge of the keele which is all one with the bottome of the
dead rising, must be an upward toward the sooth marke, they use the backe
side of one of the mouldes for a shallowing mould.

p.s:
To my very good frende
Mr. Thomas Hariots
at Durham house
these

[Note:
This important letter to Harriot from Nathaniel Torporley foretells Torporley's first meeting with François Viète, the 'French Apollon'. Unfortunately, although the letter is marked '16 Sept', no year is given. However, it must have been written before Viète's death in 1603. For further arguments about the dating, see below.
Later accounts of Torporley described him as 'amanusenis' or perhaps secretary to Viète. It seems, therefore, that, as suggested by this letter, Torporley did indeed stay for a few weeks or months in Paris, during which time he was in regular contact with Viète, perhaps copying or transcribing his mansucripts. This would explain the presence of a sheet in Harriot's mansucripts marked 'A problem of Viète from Torporley'. More importantly, it would explain Harriot's access to all the works of Viète, of which only a few copies were printed and which were not easily available even in France.
Harriot began working his way systematically through Viète's Zeteticorum libri quinque on 29 August 1600 (see Add MS 6782, f. 481). This suggests either that Torporley had already returend to England by then, bringing with him copies of Viète's books, or that he had them sent to Harriot from Paris. The letter on this page, dated 16 September, must therefore have been written earlier, perhaps the previous year, 1599. Torporley's description of Viète as the French Apollon presumably derives from the latter's Apollonius Gallus, published in Paris in 1600, but perhaps a copy of it, or at least its title, was already known to Torporley some months beforehand. It is difficult otherwise to reconcile the September date of Torporley's letter with the August date of Harriot's ntoes.
]

Good Mr. Hariots, beinge certayne how welcome to you newes of [my]
discoveries wilbe; I sende you these briefe commendations from the new
founde Tropike of Paris. For such, by my farre travaile I fynde
the greatest obliquitie of my variable Zodiake; which, by the Tables
of equall motion, ought ot have extended to the clyme Diako[???]
And thus I geve yo to understande (in some voluntarie obscuritie, and
shaminge in playne termes to come in what non putaram) the summe
of my fortunes synce my departure from London. You may [???]
in what continuall motion I have bene, that have sene Grave, [???]
Calais, Amiens, & and am now at Paris retrograde, & cursu vacuus.
And even my stile (me thinkes) discovers my exchaunge agayne of
Mars for the muses; the rather now, because I am gathering up
my ruined wittes, the better to encounter that French Apollon:
if it fortune that either his courtsie or my bouldness effecte our
conference; tomorrow beinge the daye, when if I am appoynted [by]
his Printer, as little Zacheus to climbe the tree, to gayne
a viewe of that renouwned Analist. What after followes [???]
presence I hope shortly to relate, yet resolved to consume some
weekes heare, so longe it maye be tyll I maye heare agayne
out of Englande, I have for you, if not out of season, Sim: S[???] [???] his owne plotte of the laste siege of Grave, which, because I thinke
maye be common ynough with you ere now, I therefore make
no earnest haste to sende it, but will wait some beafore being
meane while commending you to your deserved good fortunes, & my [???]
in all due respectes to your continued goodwill, I take my laeve as
Yours ever in true fidelitie
Nath. Torporley
16 Sept:

1. Some remembrances of taking the altitude of sonne
by the Astrolabe and Sea Rings.

p.s:
There are three instruments used at sea for taking of altitude, the
Astrolabe, The ring, & the staffe. Seamen use the Astrolabe The
Astolabe hath here most ancient & is used commonly & only for the
sonne; and serveth the seamans turne most specially when the sonne is
[???] becuase then they if the find the staffe very uncertayne. And when
the sea is wrought it is very hard to make any observation by it
also; because of his agitation & unquiet guaging.

But howsoever when there is need you must do as well as you may.
and therefore when you have your Astrolabe guaging as quietly as the time
will permit with his side toward the sonne according to the usual order,
you are to fit the Judex by moving it so long up & downe till the former
shine thourough the holes of both the sights at the same time. Or you finding by reason
of his agitation that the sonne will not passe iustly thourough the lower sights but be
[???] sometme higher & sometime lower. where you finde the lyst of the syghts
now as much over as under: then your Judex standeth as precisely as if the
Astrolabe had hong quietly; & sheweth the true altitude of the center of the sonne.

But if you doubt of the true guaging of the AStrolabe, you may move
your Judex quickly to the same signe on the other side & hold it towards the sonne.
If you find the sonne shine thourough as before your Astrolabe hangeth well.
Otherwise you are also to move your the Judex, till you have also the altitude on
that side. Which had, compare with the other & note the difference. The half of that
difference added to the lesse altitude or detract from the greater; And you have
the altitude of the sonne as exacte as if your Astrolabe had hung truly upright.

The other instrument called Sea Ring is of late yeares in great use with the
Portingalls & Spaniards, The making whereof & use they had about 40
yeares past of a country man of their owne a learned mathematician called
Petrus Nonius who also hath written [???] of the arte of Navigating
as well in Latin as in Spanish. And is only for taking the altitude of the
sonne as the Astrolabe. but for ease & space it much excelleth it
as also for exactnesse. for the degrees are as large agayne as in an
Astrolabe of the same signes. And in the use, there is no noe troublesome
moving up & downe any Judex as in an Astrolabe; but it guaging as the
Astrolabe, the & that side which hath a small pole be of bing holden towards
the sonne; the light passing thh thourough presently sheweth upon the degrees noted
within the ring the altitude of the sonne you desire. you are to note
that the middle of the light be it round or long is your true marke.
And if the light play by reason of his unquiet hanging; then the
middle of the play is the th hight. This instrument is continued
together for your use the last viadge with the Astrolabe , And upon your
returne it was geven to your servant Cap. Whidden, who now hath
also hath it redy for your use. By our last practice [???] I
found it much lighter then it ought to be, which is a fault also in all
the Astrolabes I have seene. By reason of your [???] speedy setting
setting forth it cnnot more be remedied; but is to be used as conveni-

niently as it may & the inconvenience shall supply I will
there fore shall be supply & [???] by the staffe in the next charte.

div.head:
1.
2. Of taking of altitudes of the sonne or starre any
starre by the corsse staffe with more exactness
then hath ben used heretofore.

p.s:
The crosse staffe is is the other instrument well knowne & used at sea
but and especially of starres. But as is it used hath ben used heretofore the
seamasters commit great errors then sometimes they are aware of
from which errors if it be purged it is then of more apte & certayne use
also for the sonne then ether the Astrolabe or Ring which I meane in
this chapter to shew.

The staffe is devided with presuppose that the end thereof in use observing should
stand in the center of the sight. And though that cannot be performed, yet
the common practiser thinketh there is little errour in putting of it
close under the that ey they behold withall: some under on the utmost corner of
that ey: some on the cheke bone: & & some on one side of the nose brid bridge of the nose.
All which placinges to some eyes, sometimes in some manner of observinges,
may prove true; & for the utmost corner of the ey to some unproportioned eyes, alwayes.

But all eyes men that have not a seat for the staffe iust agaynst the center
of the sight, as most men have not, must needs find a full altitude still
& especially in great altitudes the errour wilbe so great palpable as that it cannot
be borne withall, without artificiall correction; meaning allowance or
abatement, which hitherto have not ben made. And wher the seamen have
espied it by ether by great difference from there recconings, or comparison with
there Astrolabe; for such great altitudes they geve over the staffe.

How this errour may be knowne & reformed I have demonstrated & taught
11 yeares past in my booke called Arcticon. Now only I will remember unto
you out of the same, that which I shewed you sometime to fore & sufficient for
your use.

The best place to set the end of your staffe is the utmost corner of the seat
of that ey which you mind to behold withall. because that place is firme &
certayne without offense to the eye.
And then how farre the end of [???] the staffe doth stand from behind the center of your
sight according as it hath ben already observed when by yourself by a staffe
I have for the purpose: I have marked in a spare place of these both your
staves nere the note of 90 degrees. Betwixt two parallel lines. And the same quantity I have found
to be in Cap. Whiddous; in Douglas the masters; & many more [???] else, as in yours
& mine. The which quantity hereafter for brevity & order sake according to
the nature of the thing I call the per excentricity of the staffe.

The use of it is this: when you have according to the usuall manner
taken the sight of the sonne or starre & noted the place where the crosee stand
you are to remove him further from you & by such a quantity as the excentri-
city, which you may do by a pyre of compasses you are to consider what
sight that wilbe which is further from the ey by the quantity of the excentricity
which you may knowe by the helpe of a payre of compasses, [???] & doth
alwayes make it lesse then the former. And that sight or altitude is
as true as if the end of your staffe did stand in the center of your sight.

or else you may note the altitude as you find it first by by the
place of the crosse at first; & after set downe so much as a in degrees
or minutes as it is from the place of the crosse answereth to the qua quantity
of the excentricity, which hereafter is called the parallaxis of the staffe;
to remayne to be abated with some other things as shalbe taught
after.

If to the prime end of the staffe that is to say the end which is next the
eye nere ioyned a peece of wood of the length of the excentricity the use
wold now be somewhat reddier for your owne ey without removing the crosse
any otherwise then in the observation, or further consideration of the staffes parallaxis.

There is yet an other thing to be noted in observing of altitude by the
staffe. The seamen use comonly to leave the horison open in the observation observing,
which in deed were good if they know how much, but because of the uncertayne
coniecture they may make greater greater error then is fit to be permitted.
They have the practice by tradition from one to the other. The reason thereof they
told none in there writings, nether being demanded to they answere
any otherwise then that not doing so, the altitude wold not be true, nor
agree with the Astrolabe. Which without doubt have ben found by comparing
the staffe & the Astrolabe to gether.

By truth of demonstration which I have uttered in my Arcticon, which
here for brevity sake I omit. I have proved that the ey being above the
levell of the water at sea, doth see more then half the heavens. And therefore
from the zenith or highest poynt above our heads to the apparent horizon is
more then 90 degrees. And that surplus is the greater, according as the
ey is above the levell of the water. And therefore any high that is
taken by the staffe close, because it hath respecte to the visible horizon, is
greater then from the true horizon of the world.

Yet notwithstanding it is the surest way in using the staffe to take the
altitude close from the Horizon, because of the uncertayen opening that the
Mariners leave. Which altitude without respecte of parallaxis I call
the Apparent altitude. And then the surplus with the parallaxis is together
are to be abated to make the true altitude desired.

The quantity of which surplus I have set downe in a litle speciall
table here following according to the sondry distances of the ey from
the levell of the water.

As when the ey is one pase that is 5 foote from the levell of the water, then the
abatement is 3Ê¹. when 2 pases then 4Ê¹ & so forth as in the table.
Upon the poope of a tall ship the hight of the ey comonly is 4 or 5 pases &
then your abatement is 5Ê¹ or 6Ê¹. Upon the decke in the waste 5Ê¹. & at the
cheynes 4Ê¹ wilbe the abatement, which by triall with the load & line you may
find.

And this you ought generally to note that whensoever you observe
with the staffe, you make good your high, iust when your ship is
on the top of the surge of the sea, otherwise you may err.

Hight of the
ey above the
water in
pases.

Surplus of
the Horizon
in minuts.

those thinges being regarded which I have specifyed concerning
the staffe: you may henceforward make as true observations as need to
be: the starre or sonne being of any hight. Which before Heretofore the seamaster
ship seamaster durst not to trust to the altitude of the sonne or starre
being 60 degrees & upward. because of the difference from the Astrolabe,
imputing the error to the uncertenty in beholding; when as in deed they
know not the abatement I before spake of. the parallaxis & surplus
& that is the cause also of there experimental opening of the Horizon.
And although the error about 30 degrees in stars of ordinary [???] be be but [???] as al no great
matter of some 10Ê¹ or there aboute, yet in the hight of 60 & upward it
amounteth to nere a degree, & more. In starres of the largest size
the error was the lesse; but now by reason of the former correction, the
longer & shorter sorte will agree.

ffor taking the sonnes high also by the staffe I thinke good also to
prescribe uncertenty, & to remember unto you the meanes for it
may be done without offense to the ey.

Those men that set a glasse at the end of there staffe or end of the crosse
do [???] subiect them selves to error. It is manifest without any further reason by a common
experiment of looking thorugh glasse windows, that the thinges seene
thourough, are seen distorted, or out of there true places, by reason of refraction
of the visuall beames in the [???] arte of optickes demonstratively appro-
ved. Therefore such meanes I wish to be left.

The best way that I can præscribe, which some do also use, is to take the high of
the upper edge of the sonne, hiding the whole body with the breadth of the crosse:
And when you have don, to abate 16 minuts; because the diameter or breadth
of the sonne sonne is 32Ê¹. and then you have the hight of the center of the
sonne which you ought to have.

And this you may do without offendinge the ey, if you be wary. In the
beginning of your observation first hide the sonne with the crosse & so keep
him hidden with the orderly moving of your body & hand answerable to the
surge of the sea, & you bring him downe by litle & litle till you se only the
edge of the sonne; & if you see the other end of the crosse upon quick sight
close with the Horizon, it is well. Otherwise you must pull to or put from the
crosse untill you find that agreement.

The summe of all is this in taking altitudes by the staffe is
this. ffirst take the altitude close from the Horizon & that is called
the Apparent altitude. ffrom it abate two thinges that is the parallaxis of the staffe & the
surplus of the Horizon. The remaynder is the true hight
of the starre.

But if you take the higher edge of the sonne you must abate
16 minuts more & then you have the true altitude desired.
Examples of the premisses you shall have in the chapters of taking the altitudes of the pole.
There is yet is yet the altitude

If absolute exacteness were to be required then it is yet to be addded
to the altitude of the sonne two thinges, that is to say his parallaxis of altitude,
& angle of refraction caused by the ayre highest superficies of
the ayre: And to the altitude of the starre only the angle of
refraction. but because in your voyadge they amount not
ether one or both not to 3 [???] minuts when most, I leave them for
other place & time to be uttered.

God speed you well & send you fayre wether

div.head:
How to know your course to sayle to any place assigned; & in sayling
to keep to make true recconing to find where you are at any time; &
how farre from any place desired.

p.s:
In the art of Navigation it is præsupposed that all plottes & sea chartes have
the costes, Islands portes and other such places in them described & situated proportionally
and answerable to those thinges places they represent. as well for magnitude
& forme as true course & distance as well for true course & distance
as forme & magnitude & forme. So that those places that have
one latitude or altitude of the pole, stand in a true east & west
course; & those that are in have one meridian, stand in a true North & south
course; & so per consequence all the mid other meane courses
in the chartes signified, must be understoode to be according &
answerable to the true ppoyntes of the compasse,
& not to those of the common or any compasse
else that have variation. But if the compasse vary; by recconing
in sayling, allowance or abatement is to be made that the true
course may be knowne; else shall you be sure to misse your poste
or place desired.

And if in making of chartes such respects be not had; but that places be
set downe by the common compasse, or other compasses as
they be found, then where the compasse [???]
without respect to there variation; then where the compasses do
vary, there do places stand out of there true latitudes besides there true distances; & as in
navigation, [???] elevations of the poles for correcting your
dead reckonings would stand you in no steed. Neither could
any navigaton be performed, but only on such courses as
the planes were first found by. For upon other courses accordi
according as they are fur your deviation is greater or lesse
so good be your [???] so much should you sayle of your
purpose wether you considered but therein variation or not;
if the compasse in those such courses have a greater or lesse
variation then before in the courses originall.

And although no chartes have [???] those planes so truly situa-
ted as they aought according to arte

[Note:
This is a key page in which Harriot sets out his calculations of population under the conditions set out in Add MS 6782, f. 31v, and Add MS 6788, f. 537, namely, that each male–female pair gives birth to a child each year, alternately male and female, and that those children begin to reproduce after 20 years. All survive indefinitely.
Harriot gives no verbal explanation of the calculations, and there are only a few surviving rough diagrams like that in Add MS 6788, f. 554.
Take the calculations for 30 years as an example. Now there are 15 males born to the original couple; these are marked 'a'. Meanwhile, the 5 oldest males have begun to reproduce, giving birth to 5 + 4 + 3 + 2 + 1 = 15 male children. This sum can be calculated by the rule n(n+1)2, giving the nth triangular number. This calculation is marked 'b'.
The calculations for subsequent years follow a similar pattern. At 50 years, the second generation, measured by triangular numbers, has begun to reproduce. The third generation is therefore measured by sums of triangular numbers, that is, pyramidal numbers, calculated by the rule n(n+1)(n+2)6. This calculations is marked 'c'.
And so on.
]

3. That all are living at the end
of 240 yeres.

div.p:
[Note: After adding the number of males and females, Harriot multiplies the total population by 3. This suggests that his calculations are related to the biblical chronology of some of the surrounding pages, the three pairs being the three sons of Noah (Shem, Ham, Japheth) and their wives. ]

[Note:
This folios takes up the calculation suggested in Add MS 6788, f. 554. The numbered list across the top of the sheet shows the numbers of male children for three generations, assuming that each male fathers a male child every two years for 20 years.
The first ten entries are the offspring of a single male.
The next twenty entries show the number of males in the second generation, numbered by the sequence 1, 2, 3, 4, ..., 8, 9, 10, 9, 8, ..., 4, 3, 2, 1.
The enxt twenty entries who the number of males in the third generation, numbered by the sequence 1, 3, 6, 10, ..., 55, 62, 69, 73, 75, 75, 73, ... (see also Add MS 6788, f. 544).
]
